text.div:
NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
Encounter 0..*EncounterAn interaction during which services are provided to the patient
meta S0..1MetaMetadata about the resource
lastUpdated S0..1instantWhen the resource last changed
identifier S0..*IdentifierIdentifier(s) by which this encounter is known
system S1..1uriThe namespace for the identifier value
value S1..1stringThe value that is unique
status S1..1codeplanned | arrived | triaged | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled +
class S1..1CodingClassification of patient encounter
type S1..*CodeableConceptSpecific type of encounter
Binding: US Core Encounter Type (extensible): Valueset to describe the Encounter Type

subject S1..1Reference(US Core Patient Profile S | Group)The patient or group present at the encounter
participant S0..*BackboneElementList of participants involved in the encounter
type S0..*CodeableConceptRole of participant in encounter
period S0..1PeriodPeriod of time during the encounter that the participant participated
individual S0..1Reference(US Core Practitioner Profile S | US Core PractitionerRole Profile | US Core RelatedPerson Profile)Persons involved in the encounter other than the patient
period S0..1PeriodThe start and end time of the encounter
reasonCode S0..*CodeableConceptCoded reason the encounter takes place
reasonReference S0..*Reference(US Core Condition Problems and Health Concerns Profile S | US Core Condition Encounter Diagnosis Profile S | US Core Procedure Profile | Observation | ImmunizationRecommendation)Reason the encounter takes place (reference)
hospitalization S0..1BackboneElementDetails about the admission to a healthcare service
dischargeDisposition S0..1CodeableConceptCategory or kind of location after discharge
Binding: US Core Discharge Disposition (preferred): National Uniform Billing Committee, manual UB-04, UB form locator 17

location S0..*BackboneElementList of locations where the patient has been
location S1..1Reference(US Core Location Profile)Location the encounter takes place
serviceProvider S0..1Reference(US Core Organization Profile)The organization (facility) responsible for this encounter

Documentation for this format

name: USCoreEncounterProfile
title: US Core Encounter Profile
description: The US Core Encounter Profile inherits from the FHIR [Encounter](https://hl7.org/fhir/R4/encounter.html) resource; refer to it for scope and usage definitions. This profile sets minimum expectations for the Encounter resource to record, search, and fetch basic encounter information for an individual patient. It specifies which core elements, extensions, vocabularies, and value sets **SHALL** be present and constrains how the elements are used. Providing the floor for standards development for specific use cases promotes interoperability and adoption.
copyright: Used by permission of HL7 International, all rights reserved Creative Commons License

element.short: An interaction during which services are provided to the patient
element.definition: An interaction between a patient and healthcare provider(s) for the purpose of providing healthcare service(s) or assessing the health status of a patient.

constraint.human: If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain nested Resources
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL be referred to from elsewhere in the resource or SHALL refer to the containing resource
constraint.expression: contained.where((('#'+id in (%resource.descendants().reference | %resource.descendants().as(canonical) | %resource.descendants().as(uri) | %resource.descendants().as(url))) or descendants().where(reference = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists()).not()).trace('unmatched', id).empty()
constraint.xpath: not(exists(for $id in f:contained/*/f:id/@value return $contained[not(parent::*/descendant::f:reference/@value=concat('#', $contained/*/id/@value) or descendant::f:reference[@value='#'])]))

constraint.human: If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a meta.versionId or a meta.lastUpdated
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a security label

extension.valueMarkdown: When a resource has no narrative, only systems that fully understand the data can display the resource to a human safely. Including a human readable representation in the resource makes for a much more robust eco-system and cheaper handling of resources by intermediary systems. Some ecosystems restrict distribution of resources to only those systems that do fully understand the resources, and as a consequence implementers may believe that the narrative is superfluous. However experience shows that such eco-systems often open up to new participants over time.

constraint.human: A resource should have narrative for robust management

element.short: Logical id of this artifact
element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

element.short: Metadata about the resource
element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Version specific identifier
element.definition: The version specific identifier, as it appears in the version portion of the URL. This value changes when the resource is created, updated, or deleted.
element.comment: The server assigns this value, and ignores what the client specifies, except in the case that the server is imposing version integrity on updates/deletes.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: When the resource last changed
element.definition: When the resource last changed - e.g. when the version changed.
element.comment: This value is always populated except when the resource is first being created. The server / resource manager sets this value; what a client provides is irrelevant. This is equivalent to the HTTP Last-Modified and SHOULD have the same value on a [read](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/http.html#read) interaction.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Identifies where the resource comes from
element.definition: A uri that identifies the source system of the resource. This provides a minimal amount of [Provenance](provenance.html#) information that can be used to track or differentiate the source of information in the resource. The source may identify another FHIR server, document, message, database, etc.
element.comment:
In the provenance resource, this corresponds to Provenance.entity.what[x]. The exact use of the source (and the implied Provenance.entity.role) is left to implementer discretion. Only one nominated source is allowed; for additional provenance details, a full Provenance resource should be used. 

This element can be used to indicate where the current master source of a resource that has a canonical URL if the resource is no longer hosted at the canonical URL.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Profiles this resource claims to conform to
element.definition: A list of profiles (references to [StructureDefinition](structuredefinition.html#) resources) that this resource claims to conform to. The URL is a reference to [StructureDefinition.url](structuredefinition-definitions.html#StructureDefinition.url).
element.comment: It is up to the server and/or other infrastructure of policy to determine whether/how these claims are verified and/or updated over time.  The list of profile URLs is a set.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Security Labels applied to this resource
element.definition: Security labels applied to this resource. These tags connect specific resources to the overall security policy and infrastructure.
element.comment: The security labels can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource. The list of security labels is a set. Uniqueness is based the system/code, and version and display are ignored.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Security Labels from the Healthcare Privacy and Security Classification System.

element.short: Tags applied to this resource
element.definition: Tags applied to this resource. Tags are intended to be used to identify and relate resources to process and workflow, and applications are not required to consider the tags when interpreting the meaning of a resource.
element.comment: The tags can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource. The list of tags is a set. Uniqueness is based the system/code, and version and display are ignored.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Codes that represent various types of tags, commonly workflow-related; e.g. "Needs review by Dr. Jones".

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation

element.short: Language of the resource content
element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: A human language.

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Contained, inline Resources
element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags In their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored
element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the resource that contains them

element.short: Identifier(s) by which this encounter is known
element.definition: Identifier(s) by which this encounter is known.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions. constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: usual | official | temp | secondary | old (If known)
element.definition: The purpose of this identifier.
element.comment: Applications can assume that an identifier is permanent unless it explicitly says that it is temporary.
element.requirements: Allows the appropriate identifier for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of identifiers.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary id for a permanent one.

binding.description: Identifies the purpose for this identifier, if known .

element.short: Description of identifier
element.definition: A coded type for the identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.
element.comment: This element deals only with general categories of identifiers.  It SHOULD not be used for codes that correspond 1..1 with the Identifier.system. Some identifiers may fall into multiple categories due to common usage.   Where the system is known, a type is unnecessary because the type is always part of the system definition. However systems often need to handle identifiers where the system is not known. There is not a 1:1 relationship between type and system, since many different systems have the same type.
element.requirements: Allows users to make use of identifiers when the identifier system is not known.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: A coded type for an identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.

element.short: The namespace for the identifier value
element.definition: Establishes the namespace for the value - that is, a URL that describes a set values that are unique.
element.comment: Identifier.system is always case sensitive.
element.requirements: There are many sets  of identifiers.  To perform matching of two identifiers, we need to know what set we're dealing with. The system identifies a particular set of unique identifiers.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The value that is unique
element.definition: The portion of the identifier typically relevant to the user and which is unique within the context of the system.
element.comment: If the value is a full URI, then the system SHALL be urn:ietf:rfc:3986.  The value's primary purpose is computational mapping.  As a result, it may be normalized for comparison purposes (e.g. removing non-significant whitespace, dashes, etc.)  A value formatted for human display can be conveyed using the [Rendered Value extension](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extension-rendered-value.html). Identifier.value is to be treated as case sensitive unless knowledge of the Identifier.system allows the processer to be confident that non-case-sensitive processing is safe.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: II.extension or II.root if system indicates OID or GUID (Or Role.id.extension or root)

element.short: Time period when id is/was valid for use
element.definition: Time period during which identifier is/was valid for use.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Organization that issued id (may be just text)
element.definition: Organization that issued/manages the identifier.
element.comment: The Identifier.assigner may omit the .reference element and only contain a .display element reflecting the name or other textual information about the assigning organization.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: II.assigningAuthorityName but note that this is an improper use by the definition of the field.  Also Role.scoper

element.short: planned | arrived | triaged | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled +
element.definition: planned | arrived | triaged | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled +.
element.comment: Note that internal business rules will determine the appropriate transitions that may occur between statuses (and also classes).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because it is a status element that contains status entered-in-error which means that the resource should not be treated as valid

binding.description: Current state of the encounter.

mapping.map: No clear equivalent in HL7 v2; active/finished could be inferred from PV1-44, PV1-45, PV2-24; inactive could be inferred from PV2-16

element.short: List of past encounter statuses
element.definition: The status history permits the encounter resource to contain the status history without needing to read through the historical versions of the resource, or even have the server store them.
element.comment: The current status is always found in the current version of the resource, not the status history.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.short: planned | arrived | triaged | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled +
element.definition: planned | arrived | triaged | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled +.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Current state of the encounter.

element.short: The time that the episode was in the specified status
element.definition: The time that the episode was in the specified status.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Classification of patient encounter
element.definition: Concepts representing classification of patient encounter such as ambulatory (outpatient), inpatient, emergency, home health or others due to local variations.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Classification of the encounter.

element.short: List of past encounter classes
element.definition: The class history permits the tracking of the encounters transitions without needing to go  through the resource history.  This would be used for a case where an admission starts of as an emergency encounter, then transitions into an inpatient scenario. Doing this and not restarting a new encounter ensures that any lab/diagnostic results can more easily follow the patient and not require re-processing and not get lost or cancelled during a kind of discharge from emergency to inpatient.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.short: inpatient | outpatient | ambulatory | emergency +
element.definition: inpatient | outpatient | ambulatory | emergency +.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Classification of the encounter.

element.short: The time that the episode was in the specified class
element.definition: The time that the episode was in the specified class.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Specific type of encounter
element.definition: Specific type of encounter (e.g. e-mail consultation, surgical day-care, skilled nursing, rehabilitation).
element.comment: Since there are many ways to further classify encounters, this element is 0..*.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Valueset to describe the Encounter Type

element.short: Specific type of service
element.definition: Broad categorization of the service that is to be provided (e.g. cardiology).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Broad categorization of the service that is to be provided.

element.short: Indicates the urgency of the encounter
element.definition: Indicates the urgency of the encounter.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Indicates the urgency of the encounter.

element.short: The patient or group present at the encounter
element.definition: The patient or group present at the encounter.
element.comment: While the encounter is always about the patient, the patient might not actually be known in all contexts of use, and there may be a group of patients that could be anonymous (such as in a group therapy for Alcoholics Anonymous - where the recording of the encounter could be used for billing on the number of people/staff and not important to the context of the specific patients) or alternately in veterinary care a herd of sheep receiving treatment (where the animals are not individually tracked).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Episode(s) of care that this encounter should be recorded against
element.definition: Where a specific encounter should be classified as a part of a specific episode(s) of care this field should be used. This association can facilitate grouping of related encounters together for a specific purpose, such as government reporting, issue tracking, association via a common problem.  The association is recorded on the encounter as these are typically created after the episode of care and grouped on entry rather than editing the episode of care to append another encounter to it (the episode of care could span years).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The ServiceRequest that initiated this encounter
element.definition: The request this encounter satisfies (e.g. incoming referral or procedure request).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: List of participants involved in the encounter
element.definition: The list of people responsible for providing the service.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.short: Role of participant in encounter
element.definition: Role of participant in encounter.
element.comment: The participant type indicates how an individual participates in an encounter. It includes non-practitioner participants, and for practitioners this is to describe the action type in the context of this encounter (e.g. Admitting Dr, Attending Dr, Translator, Consulting Dr). This is different to the practitioner roles which are functional roles, derived from terms of employment, education, licensing, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Role of participant in encounter.

element.short: Period of time during the encounter that the participant participated
element.definition: The period of time that the specified participant participated in the encounter. These can overlap or be sub-sets of the overall encounter's period.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Persons involved in the encounter other than the patient
element.definition: Persons involved in the encounter other than the patient.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The appointment that scheduled this encounter
element.definition: The appointment that scheduled this encounter.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The start and end time of the encounter
element.definition: The start and end time of the encounter.
element.comment: If not (yet) known, the end of the Period may be omitted.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Quantity of time the encounter lasted (less time absent)
element.definition: Quantity of time the encounter lasted. This excludes the time during leaves of absence.
element.comment: May differ from the time the Encounter.period lasted because of leave of absence.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: (PV1-45 less PV1-44) iff ( (PV1-44 not empty) and (PV1-45 not empty) ); units in minutes

element.short: Coded reason the encounter takes place
element.definition: Reason the encounter takes place, expressed as a code. For admissions, this can be used for a coded admission diagnosis.
element.comment: For systems that need to know which was the primary diagnosis, these will be marked with the standard extension primaryDiagnosis (which is a sequence value rather than a flag, 1 = primary diagnosis).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Reason why the encounter takes place.

mapping.map: EVN-4 / PV2-3 (note: PV2-3 is nominally constrained to inpatient admissions; HL7 v2 makes no vocabulary suggestions for PV2-3; would not expect PV2 segment or PV2-3 to be in use in all implementations )

element.short: Reason the encounter takes place (reference)
element.definition: Reason the encounter takes place, expressed as a code. For admissions, this can be used for a coded admission diagnosis.
element.comment: For systems that need to know which was the primary diagnosis, these will be marked with the standard extension primaryDiagnosis (which is a sequence value rather than a flag, 1 = primary diagnosis).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: EVN-4 / PV2-3 (note: PV2-3 is nominally constrained to inpatient admissions; HL7 v2 makes no vocabulary suggestions for PV2-3; would not expect PV2 segment or PV2-3 to be in use in all implementations )

element.short: The list of diagnosis relevant to this encounter
element.definition: The list of diagnosis relevant to this encounter.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).

element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored. constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.short: The diagnosis or procedure relevant to the encounter
element.definition: Reason the encounter takes place, as specified using information from another resource. For admissions, this is the admission diagnosis. The indication will typically be a Condition (with other resources referenced in the evidence.detail), or a Procedure.
element.comment: For systems that need to know which was the primary diagnosis, these will be marked with the standard extension primaryDiagnosis (which is a sequence value rather than a flag, 1 = primary diagnosis).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: Resources that would commonly referenced at Encounter.indication would be Condition and/or Procedure. These most closely align with DG1/PRB and PR1 respectively.

element.short: Role that this diagnosis has within the encounter (e.g. admission, billing, discharge …)
element.definition: Role that this diagnosis has within the encounter (e.g. admission, billing, discharge …).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The type of diagnosis this condition represents.

element.short: Ranking of the diagnosis (for each role type)
element.definition: Ranking of the diagnosis (for each role type).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The set of accounts that may be used for billing for this Encounter
element.definition: The set of accounts that may be used for billing for this Encounter.
element.comment: The billing system may choose to allocate billable items associated with the Encounter to different referenced Accounts based on internal business rules.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Details about the admission to a healthcare service
element.definition: Details about the admission to a healthcare service.
element.comment: An Encounter may cover more than just the inpatient stay. Contexts such as outpatients, community clinics, and aged care facilities are also included.The duration recorded in the period of this encounter covers the entire scope of this hospitalization record.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Pre-admission identifier
element.definition: Pre-admission identifier.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The location/organization from which the patient came before admission
element.definition: The location/organization from which the patient came before admission.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: From where patient was admitted (physician referral, transfer)
element.definition: From where patient was admitted (physician referral, transfer).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: From where the patient was admitted.

element.short: The type of hospital re-admission that has occurred (if any). If the value is absent, then this is not identified as a readmission
element.definition: Whether this hospitalization is a readmission and why if known.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The reason for re-admission of this hospitalization encounter.

element.short: Diet preferences reported by the patient
element.definition: Diet preferences reported by the patient.
element.comment: For example, a patient may request both a dairy-free and nut-free diet preference (not mutually exclusive).
element.requirements: Used to track patient's diet restrictions and/or preference. For a complete description of the nutrition needs of a patient during their stay, one should use the nutritionOrder resource which links to Encounter.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Medical, cultural or ethical food preferences to help with catering requirements.

element.short: Special courtesies (VIP, board member)
element.definition: Special courtesies (VIP, board member).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Special courtesies.

element.short: Wheelchair, translator, stretcher, etc.
element.definition: Any special requests that have been made for this hospitalization encounter, such as the provision of specific equipment or other things.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Special arrangements.

element.short: Location/organization to which the patient is discharged
element.definition: Location/organization to which the patient is discharged.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Category or kind of location after discharge
element.definition: Category or kind of location after discharge.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: [National Uniform Billing Committee](http://www.nubc.org/), manual UB-04, UB form locator 17

element.short: List of locations where the patient has been
element.definition: List of locations where  the patient has been during this encounter.
element.comment: Virtual encounters can be recorded in the Encounter by specifying a location reference to a location of type "kind" such as "client's home" and an encounter.class = "virtual".

Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.short: Location the encounter takes place
element.definition: The location where the encounter takes place.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: planned | active | reserved | completed
element.definition: The status of the participants' presence at the specified location during the period specified. If the participant is no longer at the location, then the period will have an end date/time.
element.comment: When the patient is no longer active at a location, then the period end date is entered, and the status may be changed to completed.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The status of the location.

element.short: The physical type of the location (usually the level in the location hierachy - bed room ward etc.)
element.definition: This will be used to specify the required levels (bed/ward/room/etc.) desired to be recorded to simplify either messaging or query.
element.comment:
This information is de-normalized from the Location resource to support the easier understanding of the encounter resource and processing in messaging or query.

There may be many levels in the hierachy, and this may only pic specific levels that are required for a specific usage scenario.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Physical form of the location.

element.short: Time period during which the patient was present at the location
element.definition: Time period during which the patient was present at the location.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The organization (facility) responsible for this encounter
element.definition: The organization that is primarily responsible for this Encounter's services. This MAY be the same as the organization on the Patient record, however it could be different, such as if the actor performing the services was from an external organization (which may be billed seperately) for an external consultation.  Refer to the example bundle showing an abbreviated set of Encounters for a colonoscopy.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Another Encounter this encounter is part of
element.definition: Another Encounter of which this encounter is a part of (administratively or in time).
element.comment: This is also used for associating a child's encounter back to the mother's encounter.Refer to the Notes section in the Patient resource for further details.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: When the resource last changed

binding.description: Valueset to describe the Encounter Type
[National Uniform Billing Committee](http://www.nubc.org/), manual UB-04, UB form locator 17
